types.apps: Items of this type are applications that are intentionally created to be Vim-like in some respect (possibly disabled by default). Less Vim-like applications are in "Configurable" section.
types.plugs: Items of this type are plugins for applications that make them behave Vim-like to various extent.
types.confs: Items of this type have bindings that are either already similar or configurable to resemble Vim-like behaviour to a degree.

items.name: Cream-Browser
items.descr: A Vim-like lightweight Web browser with [Vimperator] interface.

items.name: dwb
items.descr: Quite nicely done Vim-like browser, modulo some issues with memory.

state.name: discontinued
state.comment: GTK+ bindings for WebKit leak.

items.name: jumanji
items.descr: The idea behind jumanji is a Web browser that provides a minimalistic and space saving interface as well as an easy usage that mainly focuses on keyboard interaction like [Vimperator] does.

items.name: luakit
items.descr: Fast, small, WebKit based browser framework extensible by Lua.

items.name: next
items.descr: A keyboard-oriented, extensible web-browser designed for power users.
items.ui: WebKit or WebEngine/Blink, Qt or GTK+

items.name: qutebrowser
items.descr: Qutebrowser is a keyboard-focused browser with a minimal GUI.

items.name: surf
items.descr: Ultra-minimalistic Web browser.
comments: supports XEmbed protocol (instead of tabs)
process per tab

items.name: Uzbl
items.descr: Web interface tools which adhere to the unix philosophy.
comments: requires configuration (syntax wasn't really obvious)
process per tab

items.name: Vimprobable
items.descr: A lean stand-alone web browser optimised for full keyboard control (inspired by [Vimperator]).
comments: didn't have history and cookies (claimed that this is for security)

items.name: vimb
items.descr: Vim-like browser based on the WebKit engine and the GTK toolkit.

items.name: wyeb
items.descr: A vim-like webkit2gtk web browser.

items.name: xombrero
items.descr: A minimalist's Web browser, which strives to be Vim-like for heavy keyboard users while maintaining traditional Web browser behavior.
comments: formerly known as xxxterm

items.name: Vieb
items.descr: Vim Inspired Electron Browser - Vim bindings for the web by design.

items.name: lynx
items.descr: Text Web browser.
comments: has Vim-like mode (`-vikeys` command-line option)

items.name: Netrik
items.descr: A simplistic text mode (character cell display) Web browser, similar to w3m or Lynx.

items.name: w3m
items.descr: w3m is a text-based Web browser as well as a pager like more or [less].

items.name: aerc
items.descr: Highly efficient and extensible terminal email client.

items.name: meli
items.descr: terminal email client for BSDs/Linux/macos, multiple account support, Maildir / mbox / notmuch / IMAP / JMAP / NNTP (Usenet).
comments:
E-mail submission backends

- SMTP
- Pipe to shell script
- Server-side submission when supported

Non-exhaustive list of features

- TLS
- email threading support
- multithreaded, async operation
- optionally run your editor of choice inside meli, with an embedded xterm-compatible terminal emulator
- plain text configuration in TOML
- ability to open emails in UI tabs and switch to them
- optional sqlite3 index search
- override almost any setting per mailbox, per account
- contact list (+read-only vCard and mutt alias file support)
- forced UTF-8 (other encodings are read-only)
- configurable shortcuts
- theming
- NO_COLOR support
- ascii-only drawing characters option
- view text/html attachments through an html filter command (w3m by default)
- pipe attachments/mail to stuff
- use external attachment file picker instead of typing in an attachment's full path
- GPG signing, encryption, signing + encryption
- GPG signature verification
Manpages also available online. Read [meli(7)](https://meli-email.org/documentation.html#meli.7) first for a tutorial.
`#meli` on OFTC IRC

items.name: Mutt
items.descr: Mutt is a small but very powerful text-based mail client for Unix operating systems.

items.name: NeoMutt
items.descr: A fork of [mutt], intendted to reignite the development.

items.name: notmuch
items.descr: E-mail indexer/framework, which provides plugin for Vim.

items.name: sup
items.descr: A console-based e-mail client for people with a lot of e-mail.

items.name: wyrd
items.descr: A text-based front-end to [remind](https://dianne.skoll.ca/projects/remind/), a sophisticated calendar and alarm program.

items.name: Amp
items.descr: A complete text editor for your terminal.
comments: Makes one think of things like Sublime and SpaceVim.

items.name: bvi
items.descr: A display-oriented editor for binary files (hex editor).

items.name: bvi plus
items.descr: Fork of [bvi] hex editor with more features.

items.name: hed
items.descr: HED is a wannabe-powerful visual hexadecimal editor with focus on fast editing of very large files.

items.name: HEdit
items.descr: A Vim-like terminal-based hex editor scriptable with JS.
comments: it seems to be possible to build it without JS

items.name: hexer
items.descr: A multi-buffer editor for viewing and manipulating binary files.

items.name: hx
items.descr: Hex editor for the terminal using plain C99 + POSIX libs.

items.name: elvis
items.descr: A free Vi clone for Unix and other operating systems.

items.name: ex-vi

comments: url points to updated version of <http://ex-vi.sourceforge.net/>

items.name: Kakoune

<https://github.com/noctuid/dotfiles/blob/master/emacs/editing.org#why-not-kakoune>

items.name: neovim
items.descr: Fork of Vim.
comments: has several incompatibilities with Vim (like dropped command-line options, no interactivity on `:!`, see <https://neovim.io/doc/user/vim_diff.html>)
GUI is implemented in separate projects: <https://github.com/neovim/neovim/wiki/Related-projects#gui>

items.name: ncdu
items.descr: Disk usage browser.

items.name: Snipline

items.name: stig
items.descr: TUI and CLI for the BitTorrent client Transmission.
comments:
Works mostly like vim out of the box, but can be enhanced by putting in your `~/.config/tig/config`:
```
bind generic <Ctrl-f>   scroll-page-down
bind generic <Ctrl-b>   scroll-page-up
bind generic g move-first-line			# Move cursor to top.
bind generic G move-last-line			# Move cursor to bottom.

bind main B :toggle commit-title-graph		# Rebind G to B.
bind main G move-last-line			# Move cursor to bottom.
```

items.name: GNU Screen
items.descr: This terminal multiplexer can be configured to use some Vim-like keys, it also has command-line mode.
comments: Screen has command classes, which allow implementing modes: <https://github.com/xaizek/dotfiles/blob/496c12983935288b4308fa1bb078db3c7a75c663/screenrc#L175-L192>

items.name: tmux
items.descr: This terminal multiplexer can be configured to use some Vim-like keys, it also has command-line mode.
comments: There are [prefix keys](https://alexherbo2.github.io/config/tmux/add-prefix-mode/), which allow implementing [modes](https://alexherbo2.github.io/config/tmux/make-tmux-modal/).

Specifically, a good start is to set in your `tmux.conf`:
```ini
set-option -g status-keys vi	# Use Vi bindings in tmux command prompt.
set-window-option -g mode-keys vi	# Use Vi bindings in copy and choice mode.
```

items.name: Editra
items.descr: Editra is a multi-platform text editor with an implementation that focuses on creating an easy to use interface and features that aid in code development.
items.category: IDEs, Word Processors, Editors with Vi-modes
comments: has Vim-like editing mode: <http://editra.org/vi_emulation>

items.name: SlickEdit
items.descr: A true cross-platform, multi-language code editor, with support for over 60 languages on 9 platforms.
items.category: IDEs, Word Processors, Editors with Vi-modes
comments: has Vim-like editing mode
previously known as Visual SlickEdit

items.name: Kate
items.descr: The KDE Advanced Text Editor (Kate).
items.category: IDEs, Word Processors, Editors with Vi-modes
comments: has Vim-like editing mode

items.name: AbiWord
items.descr: AbiWord is a free word processing program similar to Microsoft Word. It is suitable for a wide variety of word processing tasks.
items.category: IDEs, Word Processors, Editors with Vi-modes
comments: has Vim-like bindings: <http://recycledelectron.blogspot.com/2009/01/vi-and-emacs-key-bindings-in-abiword.html>

items.name: bash
items.descr: An sh-compatible shell that incorporates useful features from the Korn shell (ksh) and C shell (csh).
comments: has Vim-like bindings: set -o vi
you can see current mode by adding `set show-mode-in-prompt On` to `~/.inputrc`

items.name: fish

comments: see <https://fishshell.com/docs/current/index.html#command-line-editor> and <https://fishshell.com/docs/current/index.html#vi-mode-commands>

items.name: zsh
items.descr: An extended Bourne shell with a large number of improvements, including some features of [bash], ksh, and tcsh.
comments: has Vim-like bindings: bindkey -v

visual mode: <https://github.com/b4b4r07/zsh-vimode-visual>
see also [zsh-vi-mode] plugin

items.name: tcsh

comments: has Vim-like bindings: bindkey -v

items.name: KornSHell
items.descr: An early UNIX shell.
comments: has Vim-like bindings: set -o vi

items.name: GNU ReadLine
items.descr: The library provides a set of functions for use by applications that allow users to edit command lines as they are typed in.
comments: add `set editing-mode vi` to `~/.inputrc` to enables Vim-like mode in all applications that use readline

items.name: xzgv
items.descr: Image viewer with at least j/k mapped.

items.name: Evince
items.descr: A document viewer for multiple document formats.
languages: C and a bit of C++
comments: has h/j/k/l mappings

items.name: MuPDF
items.descr: A lightweight PDF and XPS viewer.
comments: bindings are relatively Vim-like

items.name: Okular
items.descr: A universal document viewer developed by KDE.
comments: supports h/j/k/l

items.name: AppGrid
items.descr: macOS window manager with Vim–like hotkeys.

items.name: bspwm
items.descr: A tiling window manager based on binary space partitioning.

items.name: euclid
items.descr: Window manager with kind of Vim-like default mappings.

items.name: howm
items.descr: A lightweight, X11 tiling window manager that is promises to behave like Vim (objects/motions/count).
comments: tries to follow Unix-way too much (see next comment)
I used the word "promises" in the description because howm demonstrated severe issues with input processing when I gave it a try, drawing it useless

items.name: i3
items.descr: Tiling WM.
comments: it seems to be possible to define Vim-like modes and there are some predefined ones

items.name: sway
items.descr: An i3-compatible Wayland compositor.

items.name: wmii
items.descr: A small, scriptable window manager, with a 9P filesystem interface and an acme-like layout.
comments: has basic Vi bindings by default

items.name: rexima
items.descr: Vim-like audio-mixer alternative to alsamixer.

items.name: PAmix
items.descr: ncurses/curses pulseaudio mixer in C++ similar to pavucontrol.

items.name: Astroid
items.descr: A keyboard-driven GUI frontend for the notmuch email indexer.

items.name: lnav
items.descr: An advanced terminal log file viewer for the small-scale.

items.name: calcurse
items.descr: Terminal calendar and scheduling application with some Vim-like keys by default.

items.name: cfiles
items.descr: An ncurses file manager written in C with vim like keybindings.  It aims to provide an interface like [ranger] while being lightweight, fast and minimal.

items.name: nnn
items.descr: A tiny full-featured terminal file manager.

items.name: hunter
items.descr: ranger-like file browser, but a little more Emacs-flavoured.

items.name: noice
items.descr: Small file browser.
comments: very minimalistic
try this for code (original link doesn't work): <https://github.com/chrisw310/noice>

items.name: rover
items.descr: A small file browser that aims to be simple, fast and portable.

items.name: CopyQ
items.descr: Clipboard manager with advanced features, which claims "support for simple Vim-like editor and shortcuts".

items.name: ncmpc
items.descr: MPD client, which is somewhat Vim-like.

items.name: ncmpcpp
items.descr: MPD client, which is somewhat Vim-like.
comments:
The navigation can quite easily be made to behave like vim with some keyboard configurations in `~/.config/ncmpcpp/bindings`:
```
def_key "j"
  scroll_down
def_key "k"
  scroll_up
def_key "h"
  previous_column
def_key "l"
  next_column
def_key "ctrl-b"
  page_up
def_key "ctrl-u"
  page_up
def_key "ctrl-f"
  page_down
def_key "ctrl-d"
  page_down
def_key "g"
  move_home
def_key "G"
  move_end
def_key "n"
  next_found_item
def_key "N"
  previous_found_item
```

items.name: NetHack
items.descr: Rougue-like game with h/j/k/l.

items.name: rekonq
items.descr: A Web browser for KDE based on WebKit.  Has basic Vim-like keys.

items.name: rtv
items.descr: Reddit terminal viewer provides a text-based interface to view and interact with reddit.

state.name: discontinued
state.comment: The author doesn't like reddit anymore.

items.name: urxvt
items.descr: Fork of rxvt terminal emulator that adds Unicode support.
comments: looks like it's possible to make it somewhat Vim-like: <https://github.com/ervandew/urxvt-vim-scrollback>

items.name: VisiData
items.descr: An interactive terminal multitool for tabular data.

items.name: WeeChat
items.descr: The extensible IRC client.
comments: bindings can be configured to be like in Vi
see <https://github.com/GermainZ/weechat-vimode>

items.name: xpdf
items.descr: Xpdf is a free PDF viewer and toolkit, including a text extractor, image converter, HTML converter, and more. Most of the tools are available as open source.
comments: Can be configured to be somewhat Vim-like: <http://stackoverflow.com/a/11241095>

items.name: rtorrent
items.descr: A text-based ncurses BitTorrent client.
comments: There is a patch for Vim-like keys: <https://github.com/spcmd/rtorrent-ps/blob/master/vi_keybindings-spcmd.patch>

items.name: htop
items.descr: An interactive system-monitor process-viewer and process-manager.
comments: There is a patch for Vim-like keys: <https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?pid=726353#p726353>
There's also a maintained version of this patch at <https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/htop-vim/>

items.name: btop++
items.descr: A terminal monitor of resources
comments: Setting `vim_keys = True` in config enables minimal Vim controls

items.name: Cypht
items.descr: Web-based email client for multiple accounts.

items.name: Tiny Tiny RSS
items.descr: Web-based news feed (RSS/Atom) reader and aggregator.

items.name: DuckDuckGo
items.descr: An Internet search engine that emphasizes protecting searchers' privacy and avoiding the filter bubble of personalized search results.
comments: Somewhat Vim-like keys are available, but shortcuts do conflict with Vim-like browsers/plugins, which makes them significantly less useful.

items.name: GitHub
items.descr: An interactive system-monitor process-viewer and process-manager.
comments: Somewhat Vim-like keys are available, but shortcuts do conflict with Vim-like browsers/plugins, which makes them significantly less useful.

items.name: GMail
items.descr: Google mail.
comments: Somewhat Vim-like keys are available, but shortcuts do conflict with Vim-like browsers/plugins, which makes them significantly less useful.

items.name: Habr
items.descr: Russian collaborative blog with elements of social network.
comments: Somewhat Vim-like keys are available, but shortcuts do conflict with Vim-like browsers/plugins, which makes them significantly less useful.

items.name: vim-anywhere
items.descr: Spawn a vim buffer from any text input in the operating system.

items.name: ipython
items.descr: Interactive Python shell.
comments:
It no longer uses readline for input, so it must be configured in the ipython profile `~/.ipython/profile_default/ipython_config.py` itself ([reference](https://gist.github.com/sstirlin/c3c207b1052b613ab9554b4ebdfc3f35)):
```ini
c.TerminalInteractiveShell.editing_mode = "vi"
```

items.name: GHCi
items.descr: Interactive Haskell environment.
comments:
It uses [haskeline](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/haskeline) instead of readline. Put this in `~/haskeline`:
```yaml
editMode: Vi
```

items.name: vimpdb
items.descr: An integration of the python debugger `pdb` and vim.

items.name: git
items.descr: Distributed version control of source code.
comments:
Nothing's better than the real deal. Tell git to use vim when editing commit messages, interactive rebase etc. by putting in your `~/.config/git/config`:
```ini
[user]
    editor = vim
```

items.name: mercurial (hg)
items.descr: Distributed version control of source code.
comments:
Put in your `~/.config/hg/hgrc`:
```ini
[ui]
    editor = vim
```

items.name: aptitude
items.descr: ncurses interface for APT on Debian-derived Linux distros.
comments: The [keybindings](https://www.debian.org/doc/manuals/aptitude/ch02s05s02.en.html) are already Vim-like.
